tasks.title: Charset

<!-- Set character encoding for the document -->

tasks.title: X-UA-Compatible
tasks.explications: The X-UA-Compatible meta tag is present.
tasks.code:
<!-- Instruct Internet Explorer to use its latest rendering engine -->
<meta http-equiv="x-ua-compatible" content="ie=edge">

tasks.title: Viewport
tasks.explications: The viewport is declared correctly.
tasks.code:
<!-- Viewport for responsive web design -->
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, viewport-fit=cover">

tasks.title: Title
tasks.explications: A title is used on all pages (SEO: Google calculates the pixel width of the characters used in the title, and it cuts off between 472 and 482 pixels. The average character limit would be around 55-characters).
tasks.code:
<!-- Document Title -->
<title>Page Title less than 55 characters</title>

tasks.title: Description
tasks.explications: A meta description is provided, it is unique and doesn't possess more than 150 characters.
tasks.code:
<!-- Meta Description -->
<meta name="description" content="Description of the page less than 150 characters">

tasks.title: Favicons

links.text: Favicons, Touch Icons, Tile Icons, etc. Which Do You Need? - CSS Tricks

tasks.explications: Each favicon has been created and displays correctly. If you have only a favicon.ico, put it at the root of your site. Normally you won't need to use any markup. However, it's still good practice to link to it using the example below. Today, PNG format is recommended over .ico format (dimensions: 32x32px).
tasks.code:
<!-- Standard favicon -->
<link rel="icon" type="image/x-icon" href="https://example.com/favicon.ico">
<!-- Recommended favicon format -->
<link rel="icon" type="image/png" href="https://example.com/favicon.png">

tasks.title: Apple Web App Meta
tasks.explications: Apple meta-tags are present.
tasks.code:
<!-- Apple Touch Icon (at least 200x200px) -->
<link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="/custom-icon.png">

<!-- To run web application in full-screen -->
<meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes">

<!-- Status Bar Style (see Supported Meta Tags below for available values) -->
<!-- Has no effect unless you have the previous meta tag -->
<meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-status-bar-style" content="black">

tasks.title: CSS Critical

links.text: Critical by Addy Osmani on GitHub

tasks.explications: The CSS critical (or "above the fold") collects all the CSS used to render the visible portion of the page. It is embedded before your principal CSS call and between <style></style> in a single line (minified).

tasks.title: CSS order
tasks.explications: All CSS files are loaded before any JavaScript files in the <head>. (Except the case where sometimes JS files are loaded asynchronously on top of your page).

tasks.title: noscript tag
tasks.explications: Use <noscript> tag in the HTML body if a script type on the page is unsupported or if scripting is currently turned off in the browser. This will be helpful in client-side rendering heavy apps such as React.js, see examples.

You need to enable JavaScript to run this app.
</noscript>

tasks.title: Goals to achieve
tasks.explications:
Your pages should reach these goals:
First Meaningful Paint under 1 second
Time To Interactive under 5 seconds for the "average" configuration (a $200 Android on a slow 3G network with 400ms RTT and 400kbps transfer speed) and under 2 seconds for repeat visits
Critical file size under 170Kb gzipped

links.text: Size Limit: Make the Web lighter

tasks.title: Minified HTML
tasks.explications: Your HTML is minified.

tasks.title: Lazy loading
tasks.explications: Images, scripts and CSS need to be lazy loaded to improve the response time of the current page (See details in their respective sections).

tasks.title: Cookie size
tasks.explications: If you are using cookies be sure each cookie doesn't exceed 4096 bytes and your domain name doesn't have more than 20 cookies.

tasks.title: Third party components
tasks.explications: Third party iframes or components relying on external JS (like sharing buttons) are replaced by static components when possible, thus limiting calls to external APIs and keeping your users activity private.

tasks.title: DNS resolution
tasks.explications: DNS of third-party services that may be needed are resolved in advance during idle time using dns-prefetch.
tasks.code: <link rel="dns-prefetch" href="https://example.com">

tasks.title: Preconnection
tasks.explications: DNS lookup, TCP handshake and TLS negotiation with services that will be needed soon is done in advance during idle time using preconnect.
tasks.code: <link rel="preconnect" href="https://example.com">

tasks.title: Prefetching
tasks.explications: Resources that will be needed soon (e.g. lazy loaded images) are requested in advance during idle time using prefetch.
tasks.code: <link rel="prefetch" href="image.png">

tasks.title: Preloading
tasks.explications: Resources needed in the current page (e.g. scripts placed at the end of <body>) in advance using preload.
tasks.code: <link rel="preload" href="app.js">
